title.p: Optimizing Statin Therapy: Role of Patient-Centered Care

contrbtr_pre_content.p: As an organization accredited by the ACCME, Medscape, LLC, requires everyone who is in a position to control the content of an education activity to disclose all relevant financial relationships with any commercial interest. The ACCME defines "relevant financial relationships" as financial relationships in any amount, occurring within the past 12 months, including financial relationships of a spouse or life partner, that could create a conflict of interest.

Medscape, LLC, encourages Authors to identify investigational products or off-label uses of products regulated by the US Food and Drug Administration, at first mention and where appropriate in the content.

slide_intro.p: The goal of this activity is to improve clinicians' knowledge and competence in optimizing statin therapy.

Before you begin this activity, please assess your clinical knowledge by completing this brief survey. Answering these questions again after the activity will allow you to see what you learned and to compare your answers with those of your peers.

sec_txt.h3: Optimizing Statin Therapy: Role of Patient-Centered Care
What Are Your Patients' Needs and Risks? Pick the Right Statin for Your Patient

ul.li: Clinicians must match the right statin to the patient as an individual
Different statins have different properties, breakdowns, and intensities

sec_txt.h3: Key Points to Get Across to Your Patient
Relationship Between LDL-C Reduction and CHD Relative Risk [5]

ul.li: The Cholesterol Treatment Trialists' survey analyzed 175,000 patients
For every 39 mg/dL lowering of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, cardiovascular (CV) events are reduced by 22%
With a dialog at the onset, many adverse events (AEs) can be avoided

sec_txt.h3: Choose the Right Statin; Not All Statins Are Created Equal

ul.li: The issue of a drug/drug interaction is very real and most patients treated with statins are taking multiple medications

sec_txt.h3: Statin Safety in HIV on ART [7]

ul.li: Any medication that is lipophilic, that is going through the liver, has more potential for metabolism pathway issues, especially with patients who have a fatty liver

Pitavastatin, approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 2009, avoids the cytochrome (CYP) pathway of metabolism and has substantially fewer drug interactions than other statins. It has the potential to be the preferred statin in patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), especially in coinfected patients
Not everybody needs to have a very high-intensity statin
Ms Ross: You really do not need to use a cannon to get a butterfly
Certain statins are much safer when patients are on multiple medications or multiple supplements
Foods should be discussed for interactions as well

Some statins do not utilize the cytochrome P450 (CP450) pathway
These statins are effective in treating LDL cholesterol to goal

sec_txt.h3: Pitavastatin and Pravastatin: Minimal CYP Involvement [9]

ul.li: Pitavastatin does not have the drug-drug interactions that you see with the other statins
Pravastatin is also as easy to metabolize as is fluvastatin but, depending on the dose, the patient is only going to get a 20%, 30%, or 35% reduction in LDL
In most cases, a 40% to 45% reduction in LDL is needed and pitavastatin would be an option to get patient to goal
The main 3 culprits for interactions and myopathy are lovastatin, simvastatin, and atorvastatin
Beware of interactions with antidepressants, the psychotropic medications, the azole antifungals, and various antibiotics
Combining calcium channel blockers and atorvastatin can cause musculoskeletal pain

sec_txt.h3: Main Message Regarding AEs and Statins

ul.li: Let patients know that it is possible that they could have a side effect
If they do, tell them to come in and have a discussion to find a cholesterol medication with fewer side effects

sec_txt.h3: Risk of T2D Lower With Some Statins [12,13]

ul.li: Educate patients on the differences in statins
Different patients are candidates for different statins
Much of the country has either metabolic syndrome or is diabetic and has issues with glucose metabolism

Clinicians need to think about which statins have the best data in glucose intolerance
That would be pitavastatin primarily, followed by pravastatin
Involve a team of health care professionals to address lifestyle challenges

sec_txt.h3: No Link Between Statins and Dementia: Randomized Clinical Trial Evidence [16]

ul.li: Clinical inertia can be mitigated by a team approach
Physicians, nurses, nurse practitioners (NPs), physician assistants (PAs), medical assistants, nutritionists, and pharmacists can help with patient questions, follow-up, and concerns
Office staff can also help with insurance issues
It takes a village

p.em: This content has been condensed for improved clarity.

slide_intro.p: What did you learn from this activity? Please click on the "Next" button to proceed to a brief survey to see how your knowledge improved after the education. You can also see how your answers compare with those of your peers.

ACC = American College of Cardiology
AHA = American Heart Association
ART = antiretroviral therapy
AUC = area under the curve
BMI = body mass index
CAD = coronary artery disease
CHD = coronary heart disease
CI = confidence interval
CK = creatine kinase
CKD = chronic kidney disease
CV = cardiovascular
CYP = cytochrome
CYP450 = cytochrome P450
DM = diabetes mellitus
FBG = fasting blood glucose
FDA = US Food and Drug Administration
FMO = flavin-containing monooxygenase
HCP = healthcare provider
HIV = human immunodeficiency virus
HR = hazard ratio
HTN = hypertension
LDL = low-density lipoprotein
LDL-C = low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol
MAO = monoamine oxidase
MI = myocardial infarction
NAT = N-acetyltransferase
NLA = National Lipid Association
NP = nurse practitioner
OR = odds ratio
PA = physician assistant
PI = protease inhibitor
PUFA = polyunsaturated fatty acid
RCT = randomized controlled trial
T2D = type 2 diabetes

Meade LT. Barriers to achieving LDL cholesterol goals. US Pharm 2007;32:66-71.

Srinivas NR. Cranberry juice ingestion and clinical drug-drug interaction potentials; review of case studies and perspectives. J Pharm Pharm Sci. 2013;16:289-303.
Orringer CE, Jacobson TA, Saseen JJ, et al. Update on the use of PCSK9 inhibitors in adults: recommendations from an Expert Panel of the National Lipid Association. J Clin Lipidol. 2017;11:880-890

bkmtr_front.p: The educational activity presented above may involve simulated case-based scenarios. The patients depicted in these scenarios are fictitious and no association with any actual patient is intended or should be inferred.

The material presented here does not necessarily reflect the views of Medscape, LLC, or companies that support educational programming on medscape.org. These materials may discuss therapeutic products that have not been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration and off-label uses of approved products. A qualified healthcare professional should be consulted before using any therapeutic product discussed. Readers should verify all information and data before treating patients or employing any therapies described in this educational activity.
